Some server sources don’t have it named rights, it might be userrights, etc. You need to find out with another command, and change rights to whatever the variable is.

item.title: ::unban
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

else if(command.equalsIgnoreCase("unban") && rights >= 3) { String unban = command.substring(10); try { File banned = new File("./data/bannedusers.txt"); if(banned.exists()) { File temp = new File(banned.getAbsolutePath() + ".tmp"); BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(new FileReader(banned)); PrintWriter out = new PrintWriter(new FileWriter(temp)); String line = null; while((line = reader.readLine()) != null) { if(!line.trim().equals(unban)) { out.println(line); out.flush(); } } out.close(); reader.close(); } else { System.out.println("ERROR!!!!!!"); } } catch(IOException e) { } }

item.title: ::unban
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

Oops, add a max value to where you call substring.
You won’t know what I meant, so I’ll do it for you… -.-.

else if(command.equalsIgnoreCase("unban")) { String unban = command.substring(10); File banned = new File("./data/bannedusers.txt"); if(banned.exists()) { File temp = new File(banned.getAbsolutePath() + ".tmp"); BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(new FileReader(banned)); PrintWriter out = new PrintWriter(new FileWriter(temp)); String line = null; while((line = reader.readLine()) != null) { if(!line.trim().equals(unban)) { out.println(line); out.flush(); } } out.close(); reader.close(); } else { System.out.println("ERROR!!!!!!"); } }

item.title: ::unban
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“zezimaisme111, post:15, topic:154923”]client.java:9961: not a statement
deleteLine;
^
1 error
Press any key to continue . . .[/quote]
Oh. Hmm, I always thought deleteLine; was right…
Hmm, ok, let me have another go.[br][size=1]Posted on: October 27, 2007, 08:44:43 PM[/size][hr]Again, just wrote this into notepad, with a little help from the API =].

else if(command.equalsIgnoreCase("unban")) { String unban = command.substring(); File banned = new File("./data/bannedusers.txt"); if(banned.exists()) { File temp = new File(banned.getAbsolutePath() + ".tmp"); BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(new FileReader(banned)); PrintWriter out = new PrintWriter(new FileWriter(temp)); String line = null; while((line = reader.readLine()) != null) { if(!line.trim().equals(unban)) { out.println(line); out.flush(); } } out.close(); reader.close(); } else { System.out.println("ERROR!!!!!!"); } }

item.title: ::unban
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

Ohk, Zezima or whatever your name is, I just wrote this into notepad, no idea if it works, but it should. And after looking through the API I came across the RandomAccessFile class, and decided it might be ok. Tell me if it works.

else if(command.equalsIgnoreCase("unban") && rights >= 5) { try { String unban = command.substring(); File file = new File("./data/bannedusers"); if(file.exists()) { RandomAccessFile raf = new RandomAccessFile(f, "rw"); String inFile = raf.readLine(); if(inFile.contains(unban)) { deleteLine; } } else { System.out.println("SOMETHING WENT WRONG!!!!!!!"); } } catch(IOException e) { System.out.println("Error!"); e.printStackTrace(); } }

Read full topic

else if(command.equalsIgnoreCase("unbanall") && rights >= 5) { try { File bannedFile = new File("./data/bannedusers.cfg"); if(bannedFile.exists()) { BufferedWriter out = new BufferedWriter(new FileOutputStream(bannedFile)); out.close(); System.out.println("Unbanned users successfully cleared."); } else { System.out.println("Something went wrong"); } } catch(IOException e) { e.printStackTrace(); } }

Sorry if it doesn’t work, haha.
